pr_title: Convert TraceState to be an interface

timeline.bodyText: Move this to a package private field in ArrayBasedTraceState so it's not public
timeline.author: anuraaga
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -24,21 +21,40 @@ * *

Value is opaque string up to 256 characters printable ASCII RFC0020 characters (i.e., the * range 0x20 to 0x7E) except comma , and =. + * + *

Implementations of this interface *must* be immutable and have well-defined value-based + * equals/hashCode implementations. If an implementation does not strictly conform to these + * requirements, behavior of the OpenTelemetry APIs and default SDK cannot be guaranteed. + * + *

Implementations of this interface that do not conform to the W3C specification risk + * incompatibility with W3C-compatible implementations. + * + *

For these reasons, it is strongly suggested that you use the implementation that is provided + * here via the {@link TraceStateBuilder}. */ @Immutable -@AutoValue -public abstract class TraceState { - private static final TraceState DEFAULT = TraceState.builder().build(); +public interface TraceState { + + TraceState DEFAULT = new TraceStateBuilder().build();

replies.bodyText: I tried this, but it ended up breaking with a class loading issue like the other one. :(
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: What if it's in the builder? I think one of the two is supposed to work ok (or otherwise I guess another package private class)
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: If I were to put this into a separate class, what would I call it? TraceStateDefaultHolder?
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: I called it DefaultTraceState. Seems like an obvious enough name. :)
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: @trask Actually can you check this - will we be able to do the interface interop if this doesn't return an interface? I guess we may intercept every method in TraceStateBuilder but not sure.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText:
it's the toBuilder() method that hurts: https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java/pull/2134/files#r530758547
@jkwatson sorry to ask, would you mind turning these builders into interfaces?
replies.author: trask

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * here via the {@link TraceStateBuilder}.
          
          
            
             * here via the {@link TraceState#builder}.
timeline.author: anuraaga
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -24,21 +21,40 @@ * *

Value is opaque string up to 256 characters printable ASCII RFC0020 characters (i.e., the * range 0x20 to 0x7E) except comma , and =. + * + *

Implementations of this interface *must* be immutable and have well-defined value-based + * equals/hashCode implementations. If an implementation does not strictly conform to these + * requirements, behavior of the OpenTelemetry APIs and default SDK cannot be guaranteed. + * + *

Implementations of this interface that do not conform to the W3C specification risk + * incompatibility with W3C-compatible implementations. + * + *

For these reasons, it is strongly suggested that you use the implementation that is provided + * here via the {@link TraceStateBuilder}.

timeline.bodyText: Thinking about your question about w3c prefix, it's a bit weird. The w3c'ness is only in this builder, not the TraceState, not sure how best to deal with that. I wonder if we should remove the validation from this class and do it in the propagator?
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: yeah...it's a weird thing to be first-class in the APIs, and not constrained to be part of the propagator, TBH. I was pondering only making this class prefixed with W3C, and leaving the TraceState itself to be generic.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: I think I'd leave it as is then - the builder of TraceState being TraceStateBuilder seems clearer even with the w3c caveats.
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: This loop has a lot of shadiness :) Relies on entries.size() being invoked on every loop iteration (true in every language, but not something people expect to matter I think), and two calls to the same entries.remove(i) ouch. Let's use ListIterator.remove instead.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Thought a bit more and realized the suggestion doesn't make much sense. Hmm - let's at least add comments if nothing comes to mind to clean up in this PR.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: It doesn't actually rely on entries.size() being called each time, since we break as soon as we remove one. I'll extract out the size and add some comments.
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: Inserting at the head of ArrayList looks like lots of overhead for the standard case of having no dupes, etc. Can we instead build up in opposite order and Collections.reverse in build? We'd need to reverse when copying from parent.getEntries() but I guess that's just a couple more lines of code.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: we could also consider just waiting until the final build to de-dupe. There are options here, for sure. Luckily, it's all internal, so we can make it better whenever.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: we could put the working data into a LinkedList for easy insert efficiency, as well. there are definitely options here. Not sure how much I want to take on this PR, though.
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: Looks like we can extract a private doRemove type of method that's used in both set and remove
timeline.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Ok ok, let me get asMap in soon :P
timeline.author: anuraaga
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -217,11 +217,11 @@ void addAndUpdateEntry() {
             firstTraceState.toBuilder()
                 .set(FIRST_KEY, SECOND_VALUE) // update the existing entry
                 .set(SECOND_KEY, FIRST_VALUE) // add a new entry
-                .build()
-                .getEntries())
-        .containsExactly(
-            TraceState.Entry.create(SECOND_KEY, FIRST_VALUE),
-            TraceState.Entry.create(FIRST_KEY, SECOND_VALUE));
+                .build())
+        .asInstanceOf(type(ArrayBasedTraceState.class))
+        .extracting(ArrayBasedTraceState::getEntries)

timeline.message: Remove the un-needed TraceState Entry objects.
Add additional javadoc documenting requirements for interface implementors.
Convert the TraceStateBuilder into an interface.
Introduce an intermediate class to get around classloading cycles.
extract a method to remove an entry from the builder
add a comment about the possible inefficiency in the implementation
